Commentary Text: Kartik Tyagi to Hardik Pandya, SIX, Pandya powers Mumbai to 195/5! Tyagi bowls a full length ball on off and Hardik smokes it over long-off to finish the innings off in style. Insane hitting!
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Commentary Text: Kartik Tyagi to Hardik Pandya, SIX, fifty for Pandya! Needed only 20 balls to get there. Slightly short ball outside off and it has been thumped over long-off by Hardik for six more

Commentary Text: Kartik Tyagi to Hardik Pandya, FOUR, short and wide outside off, Hardik Pandya goes deep inside his crease and manages to reach out for it. Slaps it over extra cover and moves onto 44*

Commentary Text: Kartik Tyagi to Hardik Pandya, SIX, shuffles inside the line, picks the length early, sets himself up and swings the shortish delivery over deep mid-wicket for six more. Can he get his fifty?

For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR. Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Commentary Text: Jofra Archer to Saurabh Tiwary, out Caught by Stokes!! Another full toss by an RR bowler, but this time they manage to get a wicket. Saurabh Tiwary lofted it well, but could reach only as far as long-on. In fact, Stokes had to amble in and finish it off with a reverse cup. Good knock by Tiwary, nevertheless. Saurabh Tiwary c Stokes b Jofra Archer 34(25) [4s-4 6s-1]

Commentary Text: Rajpoot to Hardik Pandya, SIX, Pandya power! 27 runs off the over. Another full toss by Rajpoot and it has been powered over deep square leg by Pandya junior. This is scintillating stuff! Rajpoot concedes 60 runs in 4 overs - that hurts!

team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
toss: Mumbai Indians have won the toss and have opted to bat

Commentary Text: Rajpoot to Hardik Pandya, SIX, full toss! Kung Fu Pandya time as he smokes the freebie over long-on for a big one
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up. Commentary Text: Shreyas Gopal to Hardik Pandya, 1 run, watchful with this legbreak as Hardik Pandya push-drives it to long-off for one
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. Commentary Text: Shreyas Gopal to Pollard, out Bowled!! Two wickets in the same over for Gopal. He's got two in-form batsmen out. Not for the first time, are we getting to see this from the leg-spinner. Was the straighter delivery around off, this one kept low and Pollard failed to bring his bat down in time. The stumps are uprooted and Mumbai are four down. Both RR spinners choking the defending champions. Pollard b Shreyas Gopal 6(4) [6s-1]

Commentary Text: Shreyas Gopal to Pollard, SIX, Stokes tries to do a Jofra, but fails to do so. Was a tossed up delivery on off and Pollard mistimed his loft. But you see the power in those forearms. Doesn't matter even if he doesn't time it. Stokes got a hand to it and parried it over the fence

The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
toss: Mumbai Indians have won the toss and have opted to bat

Commentary Text: Shreyas Gopal to Suryakumar Yadav, out Caught by Stokes!! In his quest to take on Gopal, Suryakumar Yadav holes out to long-off. Was a loopy legbreak on off and Suryakumar Yadav lofted it straight to Stokes near the boundary. Good knock by Surya, but he would have liked to convert this start. With two new batsmen at the crease, Rajasthan have a chance to pull things back to an extent. Suryakumar Yadav c Stokes b Shreyas Gopal 40(26) [4s-4 6s-1]

Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury. team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Commentary Text: Kartik Tyagi to Ishan Kishan, out Caught by Jofra Archer!! That's a blinder by Jofra Archer at third man. One of the contenders for the catch of the season. Short ball outside off, Ishan Kishan throws his hands at it, gets a thick outside edge that abosolutely flying and Archer in the deep who had initially misjudged it, recovers well to leap and grab it in his right hand. Taking crucial wickets, hitting sixes and now taking blinders for fun. What a player! Ishan Kishan c Jofra Archer b Kartik Tyagi 37(36) [4s-4 6s-1]

Commentary Text: Kartik Tyagi to Ishan Kishan, no run, another ugly swing. Short of a length delivery around off, Ishan Kishan has a wild swing and gets an inside edge onto his knee. Struggling to get going today, not able to middle most of the deliveries he has faced so far

Commentary Text: Kartik Tyagi to Ishan Kishan, no run, very full again, Ishan Kishan goes down on his knee and squeezes it next to the pitch. Was looking for the drive, but couldn't really middle it

And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
toss: Mumbai Indians have won the toss and have opted to bat

Commentary Text: Shreyas Gopal to Suryakumar Yadav, 1 run, back of a length on middle, Surya arches back into the leg-side and punches hard through cover
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Commentary Text: Rajpoot to Ishan Kishan, SIX, it's the same thing tonight, as it was in their previous match. Quality from Archer and the glaring lack of it at the other end. This is a horrible delivery with fine leg up. Short of length at the body, Kishan swats it for six behind square. Smith gestures with his hands as if to ask what was that

There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
toss: Mumbai Indians have won the toss and have opted to bat

Commentary Text: Rajpoot to Suryakumar Yadav, SIX, this is something of a hybrid between a ramp and a pull. Short of length outside off, Surya has decided beforehand where he wants to hit it. He walks across a touch, bends a little and his bat follows an upswing in order to hoist it over short fine leg. Carries all the way
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. Commentary Text: Rajpoot to Suryakumar Yadav, wide, Suryakumar and Ishan Kishan not on the same page here. It's wide down leg again, and this slower ball bounces in front of Samson who fumbles. Kishan comes out looking for a single but he's sent back. Dives in to make the crease. There was Stokes standing at slip, so the single wasn't on at all

Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
toss: Mumbai Indians have won the toss and have opted to bat

Commentary Text: Rajpoot to Ishan Kishan, leg byes, FOUR, looks really close, this LBW shout. Given not out. Samson tells Smith that it's missing leg, so they don't take the review. Turns out to be a good call. While Rajpoot gets the inswinger going nicely with the full one, this has just pitched outside leg. Runs away for four as well

team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. Commentary Text: Jofra Archer to Ishan Kishan, no run, short of length on middle, Kishan hops and blocks
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Commentary Text: Jofra Archer to de Kock, out Bowled!! Archer hits back immediately. Leg stump uprooted off the inside edge. Just a complete lack of footwork there from de Kock. This is over 145kph, angling away from a length outside off. De Kock half-heartedly goes after it with his hands and drags it back. Another powerplay wicket for Archer who continues to be brilliant with the new ball. de Kock b Jofra Archer 6(4) [6s-1]

Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR. Commentary Text: Pattinson to Stokes, SIX, hundred for the world's best all-rounder - he has been under fire so far, but has come up trumps when is team needed it badly - Smith & co. are chuffed to bits, gets a warm hug from his partner as he raises his arms aloft - back of a length and at the stumps, pulled away nonchalantly over mid-wicket for a maximum

Commentary Text: Boult to Samson, no run, Boult shortens his length and angles this one across the right-hander, Samson went chasing and is beaten on the cut - only 4 from the over, but is it already too late for MI?
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
