team_b_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
toss: Mumbai Indians have won the toss and have opted to bat

Commentary Text: Boult to Stokes, 2 runs, Stokes gets lucky, he backed away to a slower short ball and didn't get enough on the cut - but has enough to clear the leaping fielder at extra-cover, back for the second
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Commentary Text: Bumrah to Samson, 2 runs, fifty for Samson, this has been a smashing innings from the RR star - short of a good length and just outside off, nudged in front of square on the on-side and he comes scampering back for the second. A little fist pump, a little jig and he shows the bat at the dug-out - job not yet done though

It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Commentary Text: Pattinson to Stokes, no run, Stokes attempts a cheeky little dab - moves right across his stumps and looks to paddle it fine - beaten and the ball sailed over the top of middle
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR. Commentary Text: Rahul Chahar to Samson, no run, that was close! Not sure Samson needs to take such risks, shuffled across on the paddle sweep and Chahar spotted it - pushed one flatter and quicker, Samson was caught in a tangle on the shot, might have got a bit of glove before the ball found the flap of the pad. Polite appeal for LBW is turned down, but that's a second straight good over for the Mumbai Indians

Commentary Text: Rahul Chahar to Stokes, 1 run, the snake formation from Chahar, slids one across the left-hander, dabbed in front of short third man for a single
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up. Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. Commentary Text: Krunal Pandya to Stokes, FOUR, fifty for Stokes! He's putting on a show here at Abu Dhabi. 93.9kph, Pandya follows a backing away with an in-dart. Stokes gets down and heaves it in front of square on the leg-side. Two fielders - deep mid-wicket and deep backward square leg - converge, but the ball went right in between them. Stokes gets a standing ovation from his team-mates. Can he take his team over the line?

Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. Commentary Text: Krunal Pandya to Samson, 1 run, 97kph, flat and fired in from a length, Samson stays leg-side of the ball to punch it to sweeper cover
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR. team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. Commentary Text: Pollard to Stokes, 1 run, 113.8kph, another off-pace ball, length ball, Stokes crouches a bit after walking towards off. Hammers the pull towards long-on
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Commentary Text: Pollard to Stokes, wide, 121.2kph, Stokes shimmies down the track and slightly moves leg-side. Was a length ball just outside the tramline. Stokes tried his best to reach out for it, but the ball went over his horizontal blade. Wided!

They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up. Commentary Text: Krunal Pandya to Stokes, FOUR, in the air ... and ... safe! 101.3kph, fired on leg, Stokes gets down on one leg and backs himself to clear the longer boundary with a slog sweep. Doesn't quite middle it, but gets away as it's just out of Hardik's reach. The younger Pandya ran back and to his right, put in a dive too, but in vain as the ball bounced and reached the fence

Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up. Commentary Text: Pattinson to Samson, wide, short ball wasted down the leg-side
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. Commentary Text: Pattinson to Samson, no run, a good bumper first up to the new batter. Samson picks it late and fends it into the leg-side. Stokes is keen for a single and is halfway down, gets sent back by Samson. The single was on, but the striker was never interested

Commentary Text: Pattinson to Smith, out Bowled!! 143.6kph! Pattinson wins the Australian battle and is rightly delighted. In-seamer from a length, Smith hangs back and punches sans any feet movement. Drags it onto his sticks via an inside edge. Smith stands still for a couple of second before trudging off. The dangerous partnership has been broken. Smith b Pattinson 11(8) [4s-1 6s-1]

Commentary Text: Pattinson to Stokes, 1 run, 129.6kph, change of pace. Full on middle and off, jammed towards mid-off for a single
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Commentary Text: Bumrah to Smith, SIX, wristy shot for a maximum! RR are going after Mumbai's best bowler. A full, in-angler at 144.3kph, middle-stump line, Smith shuffles across, clears his front leg and flicks it nonchalantly over deep square leg. Brilliant stuff

And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Commentary Text: Pattinson to Uthappa, out Caught by Pollard!! And, Pattinson has his revenge! 140.8kph, Pattinson pulls his length back by a fraction, Uthappa shuffles a bit to heave/pull across the line. No timing whatsoever as the ball pops up off the top part of the bat. A dolly to Pollard and the skipper pouches it with ease at mid-off. Once again, RR lose an early wicket! Uthappa c Pollard b Pattinson 13(11) [4s-2]

Commentary Text: Pattinson to Uthappa, FOUR, 137.9kph. Overpitched outside off, Uthappa takes full toll of this cross-seam freebie. Leans forward and plays a lovely drive on the walk through the gap between mid-off and extra cover

When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up. Commentary Text: Pattinson to Uthappa, no run, 138.9kph, tucks this length ball into the leg-side
team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi
team_b_11: Mumbai Indians (Playing XI): Quinton de Kock(w), Ishan Kishan, Suryakumar Yadav, Saurabh Tiwary, Hardik Pandya, Kieron Pollard(c), Krunal Pandya, James Pattinson, Rahul Chahar, Trent Boult, Jasprit Bumrah
team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR. Commentary Text: Pattinson to Uthappa, FOUR, 141kph. Uthappa greets Pattinson with a boundary. A shortish ball, not much bounce, Uthappa gets into a good position and pulls it over mid-wicket. Didn't try to over-hit and relied on timing. A good shot from the right-hander, first boundary of the innings

team_a_11: Rajasthan Royals (Playing XI): Robin Uthappa, Ben Stokes, Sanju Samson(w), Jos Buttler, Steven Smith(c), Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

team_a_subs: Preview by Kritika Naidu  Such has been the quicksilver movement in this ongoing season of the Indian Premier League that even wins in their three remaining games will not guarantee Rajasthan Royals a top-four finish. Elimination stares at them if they lose two. And if they win two of three, theoretically, they will still be in with a chance, but with little assurance.  Sunrisers Hyderabad comfortably overcame RR in their last clash despite losing both David Warner and Jonny Bairstow in the first three overs. It was Rajasthan's inability to get a par total in Dubai with runs drying up in the middle overs that really hurt them as the conditions gradually eased up for the batting side in the second innings.. The move of opening with Ben Stokes is not one that has yielded the desired results for RR yet. And a good start is almost imperative against table-toppers Mumbai Indians, who are coming off a ten-wicket trouncing of Chennai Super Kings. How Samson will tackle the left-arm pace of Boult will be a contest to watch out for.  If any team can boast of having almost all bases covered, it is the Mumbai Indians. They even have the luxury of "resting" players to "manage workload" with their substitutes doing the job just as well. For instance, Ishan Kishan stepped in seamlessly into the opening slot for Rohit Sharma, who missed out in the clash against CSK owing to a hamstring injury.  They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables.  When:Sunday, October 25, 2020 at 19:30 IST  Where:Sheikh Zayed Stadium, Abu Dhabi  What to expect: The average first-innings total in Abu Dhabi has been 147 in 10 innings, but Mumbai Indians' average score at the venue has been 185 in four. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI. Although Tyagi went for a few runs against SRH, it's unlikely they will make a change to their line-up.  Probable XI: Ben Stokes, Robin Uthappa, Sanju Samson (wk), Steven Smith (c), Jos Buttler, Riyan Parag, Rahul Tewatia, Jofra Archer, Shreyas Gopal, Ankit Rajpoot, Kartik Tyagi

Commentary Text: Boult to Uthappa, 2 runs, Boult goes fuller and Uthappa tries to meet it off the frontfoot. Goes for the drive and gets an outside edge that falls short of an in-running Chahar at backward point. The leg-break allows it to go through him and the batters collect a brace

They haven't even needed Hardik Pandya to bowl, given how vast their bowling stocks are, with their powerplay bowlers in Trent Boult and Jasprit Bumrah delivering the early wickets more often than not. Boult in the powerplay overs this year has returned 10 wickets at 16.30, conceding at just 6.79 runs per over.  Rajasthan have had their own powerplay specialist in Jofra Archer, who has picked 7 wickets in 20 overs he's bowled in that phase, conceding just at 4.65. Overall, while he has picked 15 wickets with an economy rate of 6.62, it has been the lack of support from the other end that has cost them in stark contrast. The other seamers collectively have returned 16 wickets, with an ER of 10.29, with Stokes wicketless in his eight overs, but having conceded at 10.25.  While Mumbai already have one foot in the play-offs, it's pretty much do-or-die for Rajasthan here on. While the eventual result may not be in their hand, the least they can do is try and control the controllables. There's a bit of assistance for the pacers early on on a two-paced wicket, with spin getting almost no assistance in the day game played here between DC and KKR.  Team news:  Rajasthan Royals  Although their batting order needs a bit of tweaking, the Royals seem to have found their best XI.
